docblock.description: OSS\SNMP\Exception class
A class for performing SNMP V2 queries and processing the results.

docblock.description: Get indexed SNMP values (first degree)
docblock.long-description:
Walks the SNMP tree returning an array of key => value pairs.

This is a first degree walk and it will throw an exception if there is more that one degree of values.

I.e. the following query with sample results:

walk1d( '.1.0.8802.1.1.2.1.3.7.1.4' )

  .1.0.8802.1.1.2.1.3.7.1.4.1 = STRING: "GigabitEthernet1/0/1"
  .1.0.8802.1.1.2.1.3.7.1.4.2 = STRING: "GigabitEthernet1/0/2"
  .1.0.8802.1.1.2.1.3.7.1.4.3 = STRING: "GigabitEthernet1/0/3"
  .....

would yield an array:

 1 => GigabitEthernet1/0/1
 2 => GigabitEthernet1/0/2
 3 => GigabitEthernet1/0/3

tag.name: var
tag.description: The OID to walk

tag.name: return
tag.description: The resultant values

docblock.description: Get indexed SNMP values where the array key is the given position of the OID

tag.name: var
tag.description: The OID to walk

tag.name: var
tag.description: The position of the OID to use as the key

tag.name: return
tag.description: The resultant values

docblock.description: Utility function to translate one value(s) to another via an associated array
docblock.long-description:
I.e. all elements '$value' will be replaced with $translator( $value ) where $translator is an associated array.

Huh? Just read the code below!

tag.name: param
tag.description: A scalar or array or values to translate

tag.name: param
tag.description: An associated array to use to translate the values

tag.name: return
tag.description: The translated scalar or array

docblock.description: Magic method for generic function calls
This is the MIB Extension magic
docblock.long-description:
Calling $this->useXXX_YYY_ZZZ()->fn() will instantiate an extension MIB class is the given name and this $this SNMP instance and then call fn().

See the examples for more information.

property.name: $IF_OPER_STATES
property.default: array(NULL => 'up', NULL => 'down', NULL => 'testing', NULL => 'unknown', NULL => 'dormant', NULL => 'notPresent', NULL => 'lowerLayerDown')

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface names

tag.name: return
tag.description: An array of interface names

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface aliases (e.g. as set by the interface description / port-name parameter)
docblock.long-description:
E.g. the followig SNMP output yields the shown array:

.1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.2.18.10128 = STRING: Connection to switch2 .1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.2.18.10129 = STRING: Connection to switch3 ...

 [10128] => "Connection to switch2"
 [10129] => "Connection to switch3"

tag.name: return
tag.description: An array of interface aliases

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface descriptions
docblock.long-description:
E.g. the following SNMP output yields the shown array:

.1.3.6.1.2.1.31.1.1.1.1.10128 = STRING: GigabitEthernet1/0/28 .1.3.6.1.2.1.31.1.1.1.1.10129 = STRING: GigabitEthernet1/0/29 ...

 [10128] => "GigabitEthernet1/0/28"
 [10129] => "GigabitEthernet1/0/29"

tag.name: return
tag.description: An array of interface descriptions

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface (operating) speeds
docblock.long-description:
E.g. the following SNMP output yields the shown array:

.1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.5.10128 = Gauge32: 1000000000 .1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.5.10129 = Gauge32: 100000000 ...

 [10128] => 1000000000
 [10129] => 100000000

NB: operating speed as opposed to maximum speed

tag.name: return
tag.description: An array of interface operating speeds

docblock.description: Get an array of device interface operating status (up / down)
docblock.long-description:
E.g. the follow SNMP output yields the shown array:

.1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.8.10128 = INTEGER: up(1) .1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.8.10129 = INTEGER: down(2) ...

 [10128] => 1
 [10129] => 2

tag.name: return
tag.description: An array of interface states

docblock.description: Returns an associate array of STP port IDs (key) to interface IDs (value)

tag.name: return
tag.description: Associate array of STP port IDs (key) to interface IDs (value)

property.name: $STP_X_RSTP_PORT_ROLES
property.default: array(NULL => 'disabled', NULL => 'root', NULL => 'designated', NULL => 'alternate', NULL => 'backUp', NULL => 'boundary', NULL => 'master')

docblock.description: Get the device's RSTP port roles (by given vlan id)
docblock.long-description:
Only ports participating in RSTP for the given VLAN id are returned.

This function will also convert STP port IDs to the device proper port IDs. E.g. sample output:

Array ( [10101] => 3 [10103] => 3 [10105] => 3 [5048] => 2 )

tag.name: param
tag.description: The RSTP VLAN ID to query port roles for

tag.name: param
tag.description: If true, return the string representation via self::$STP_X_RSTP_PORT_ROLES

tag.name: return
tag.description: The device's RSTP port roles (by given vlan id)

tag.name: return
tag.description: The device's CDP (Cisco Discovery Protocol) ID

docblock.description: Get the device's interfaces CDP enabled status
docblock.long-description: Applies the TruthValue post processor (self::ppTruthValue()) to turn SNMP values into true / false.

tag.name: return
tag.description: The device's interfaces CDP enabled status' (as boolean true / false)

docblock.description: Get the device's interface names as seen in CDP

tag.name: return
tag.description: The device's interface names as seen in CDP

docblock.description: Get the device's CDP neighbours (by their CDP ID) indexed by the current device's port ID

tag.name: return
tag.description: The device's CDP neighbours (by their CDP ID) indexed by the current device's port ID

docblock.description: Get the device's CDP neighbours connected port *description* indexed by the current device's port ID
docblock.long-description:
E.g. a sample call may return:

Array ( [10101] => GigabitEthernet0/1 [10102] => FastEthernet0/2 [10103] => GigabitEthernet1/0/24 [10105] => GigabitEthernet1/0/2 )

meaning, for example, that our local port with ID 10101 is connected to port GigabitEthernet0/1 on the neighbour connected to that local port. You can discover the neighbour ID via neighbourId().

tag.name: return
tag.description: The device's CDP neighbours connected port *description* indexed by the current device's port ID

docblock.description: Get the device's CDP neighbour capabilities (as a decimal integer) indexed by the current device's port ID

tag.name: return
tag.description: The device's CDP neighbour capabilities (as a decimal integer) indexed by the current device's port ID

docblock.description: CDP utility function to get all CDP neighbours and their connected ports.
docblock.long-description:
Returns an array of neighbours indexed by the neighbour CDP ID. For example:

Array ( [cr-sw03.ixdub1.opensolutions.ie] => Array ( [0] => Array ( [localPortId] => 10101 [localPort] => GigabitEthernet1/0/1 [remotePort] => GigabitEthernet0/1 )

        [1] => Array
            (
                [localPortId] => 10102
                [localPort] => GigabitEthernet1/0/2
                [remotePort] => FastEthernet0/2
            )

    )
[ ... ]

)

tag.name: return
tag.description: CDP neighbours and their connected ports
